WSC-Category 1 Collaborative Proposal: Coupled Multi-scale Economic, Hydrologic, and Estuarine Modeling to Assess Impacts of Climate Change on Water Quality Management

One of the most important questions facing our society is the potential impact of climate change on water quality, water resources and ecosystem function. Confounding issues such as urban sprawl and agricultural intensification make it difficult to determine the singular effects of climate change on water quality, ecosystem function and on the costs to achieve water quality goals. In view of the challenges facing the Chesapeake Bay (urban growth, agricultural intensification, climate change) an integrated multi-disciplinary approach is critical to provide policy makers with robust and reliable information. The approach that the research team will use is to integrate key climate, hydrologic, estuarine, and economic drivers at multiple scales which will provide water management options for the Chesapeake Bay system.

One way to assess the impacts of climate change in the face of these other stressors is to develop coupled models that incorporate the pertinent controls on the water system. The overarching goal of this project is to develop a quantifiable, predictive framework that couples biogeochemical and hydrologic drivers of terrestrial nutrient export with climate change to evaluate the effects of ecosystem management on estuarine function and costs of water quality protection. To achieve this goal, the project proposes to work broadly across common regional Chesapeake Bay watershed physiographic gradients and dominant land uses (e.g., agriculture, forest and urban) using a multi-scale model evaluation of the impact of climate change and climate variability on the hydrologic, biogeochemical, and economic drivers of water quality degradation in the Chesapeake Bay estuary. Climate data will be down scaled from global and regional climate models and applied to watershed models to predict hydrologic activity and nutrient production across five test-bed watersheds where significant investments in land management (e.g., Best Management Practices) have been made. Test-bed model results will be used to populate an economic model to quantify the optimum tradeoff between water quality improvements and their associated costs. The watershed models will then be upscaled to predict hydrologic and nutrient delivery to an estuarine model to determine estuary impacts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Estuaries, where rivers meet the sea, are among the most productive waters on Earth. Estuaries have abundant fisheries and support a wide range of plants and animals. Overuse of estuaries and the watersheds that drain into them has caused numerous problems. For example, agricultural fertilizers, which contain nitrogen and phosphorus, often run off from soils into rivers and estuaries where they have harmful effects, such as algal blooms. These algal blooms reduce the clarity of the water, ultimately rob the water of oxygen, and may even be toxic to humans and fish. Very expensive efforts are underway in many regions, such as the Chesapeake Bay and its watershed, to reduce the harmful effects of nitrogen and phosphorus pollution. However, climate change could influence the efficacy of these efforts in unknown ways.

Our project, which was conducted in collaboration with scientists at Virginia Tech and The University of Maryland, was to assess the impacts of climate change on strategies for managing nitrogen, phosphorus and sediments on the landscape. We also assessed the impact of climate change on estuarine water quality itself. For example, warming reduces the ability of an estuary to retain oxygen, which is needed by fish to breathe.

The Penn State contributions to this project were threefold.

First, Penn State scientists provided the projections of future climate to our collaborators at Virginia Tech and The University of Maryland, who assessed how climate change would influence the Chesapeake Bay and its watershed. It was found that, by mid-century, the Chesapeake Bay region would be considerably warmer throughout the year and wetter in the winter and spring.

Second, Penn State scientists addressed the problem of how to choose the projections of future climate. Climate models are the tools that scientists use to determine how the climate will change as a result of increases in greenhouse gases. There are dozens of climate models to choose from and, even though they broadly predict similar changes, the magnitude of the changes can differ. It is computationally very expensive to consider all of the climate model projections, so Penn State scientists evaluated six methods for choosing a limited number of climate models for study. It was found that the method that selecting the widest range of climate projections was the most appropriate. That is, it makes the most sense to choose models that span from the coldest to the warmest and the driest to the wettest.

Third, Penn State scientists discovered that the change in tidal range could be an important factor in future estuarine water quality. The tidal range is the range of water level experienced over the course of a day: the high tide level minus the low tide level. The tidal range influences the circulation and mixing of an estuary, which determines, for example, how much oxygen can be supplied to the bottom waters of an estuary. It was discovered that the tidal range is sensitive to the average sea level. That is, as sea level rises as a result of global warming, the tidal range changes. In many cases the tidal range increases as average sea level increases, which means that coastal flooding might be even more severe than expected from sea-level rise alone. In other words, the high tide increases even more than the average sea level. Penn State scientists discovered the influence of sea level on tidal range by looking at decades of water level measurements and by conducting simulations of tidal range using advanced computational models of estuarine circulation. Penn State scientists further discovered that the uncertainty in the trends of tidal range are large enough to create a lot of uncertainty as to how estuarine circulation might change in the future, which, by implication, means that future estuarine water quality may be significantly influenced by future changes in tidal range.

Overall, Penn State scientists added to our knowledge of how climate change will influence estuaries in the future. The knowledge gained from this study could be used to develop strategies that are more effective at reducing the harmful effects of pollution on Chesapeake Bay and other estuaries.
